urn:contentItem:5FH7-KFT1-F0HW-54CS-00000-00Financial 'House of Cards'; Conservatives Concerned; Neil's Spiel: Cryin' Over Cuts; What The Tech?!; Target To Layoff Thousands; Are You2015-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:49ZLexisNexisFinancial 'House of Cards'; Conservatives Concerned; Neil's Spiel: Cryin' Over Cuts; What The Tech?!; Target To Layoff Thousands; Are You

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: Here's why I fear we will never ever, ever get entitlement spending under control. Forget about ever really doing it, we can't even fake doing it.

Welcome, everyone. Glad to have you. I'm Neil Cavuto.

And talk about a "House of Cards", literally, because the fictional president on that fictional NetFlix show takes a fictional stab at entitlement spending and liberal blogs are going seriously nuts. But even more seriously nuts when I bring up the ridiculous reaction to this utterly ridiculous, totally made-up issue.

Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP - "YOUR WORLD", YESTERDAY)

CAVUTO: The Huffington Post detailing how Underwood's goal of zero unemployment is impossible and that even if he did get there, inflation would get out of control everywhere.

This tell you all you need to know, that even cutting entitlements on a fake show with a fake president gets this type of real irate response. This is Rome in the final days.

(END VIDEO CLIP - "YOUR WORLD", YESTERDAY)

CAVUTO: Now, you can almost guess what happens next - angry Liberals jumping on moi for them jumping on this.

This headline on a very popular media website summed it up. "Fox's Cavuto Proudly Stands with the President (No, Not Obama)". The writer goes on to explain that I was seriously rushing to a fake President Underwood's defense.

Newsflash! I wasn't rushing to anyone's defense, just wondering why so many were taking offense over something that wasn't real and a President and a whole storyline that are totally made-up. It didn't matter. I was just seriously evil.

I want you to take a look at just some of the responses.

Like this one: "Figures Cavuto loves Frank Underwood more than Barack Obama..."

Then this: "Fake President for a fake news channel."

This one I personally like: "Pravda and Tass are models for Fox News."

And then this one: "Cavuto's a troll and a midget ogre." I have no idea what that means.

"Obviously, Cavuto's OK letting our poor suffer. He makes Underwood look like Lincoln."

Then this: "What a heartless bastard this fat Fox fake is... all for cutting entitlements any way he can." Who are you calling "fat"?

Anyway, "Most people are aware that Repubs suffer Schizophrenia..", I forgot, "..mixed with racism...", I forgot that too, "...it's a dangerous combo."

Then this: "Underwood's cut to entitlements fund a $500 billion stimulus program. Cavuto didn't mention that."

Well, actually, I did mention that but who needs facts on something that's fake and thank God for at least some viewers who did know what I was getting at.

Like this guy: "This headline is so deceptive. The Fox host was ranting about a fictional character being taken seriously by left-wing websites and somehow he is defending him? This website is growing worse day by day."

Now, there were a lot of other emails like that last one. In fact, most emails were like that last one. But my point here wasn't to make me look good. I don't have to.

Anyway, my other point though was to quite seriously take a look at how difficult it is to ever get a handle on real entitlement reform because even when we're discussing a fake show, my God, we can't even fake it. And if that's the case, we really are a financial 'House of Cards'.

To political watcher Steve Moore, Sabrina Schaeffer, Julie Roginsky.

Steve, what do you think?

STEVE MOORE, HERITAGE FOUNDATION CHIEF ECONOMIST: Well, Neil, it is a (INAUDIBLE) fake character and it is a fake show. But you know what? It's not a fake crisis. This entitlement time bomb that is (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: You're feeding the beast, Moore. You're feeding the beast.

MOORE: Well, you had it exactly right. This is a real crisis. Ten thousand Americans are retiring every day. They're going on Medicare. They're going on social security. This is the Titanic headed right towards the iceberg. And shame on you for saying maybe we should start turning that ship away from the iceberg. But you're right on.

CAVUTO: But here's the thing, Sabrina. I mean, even when a fake show lobs this up, silly as it was, it gets this type of reaction. People are seriously all worked-up about it. So Sabrina, my worry with this is if we can't even get to it on a fake entitlement address, how are we ever going to get serious about it?

SABRINA SCHAEFFER, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S FORUM: Well, here's the thing, Neil, and this is where the writers got Frank Underwood totally wrong. Democrats would never have released something like Frank Underwood does on this AmWorks program without intensive persuasion messaging research. Frank Underwood would never have just talked about entitlement reform the way he did in that meeting in that scene in the show. In fact, the Independent Women's Forum did conduct a randomized controlled experiment to figure out how do we talk about it and talking about entitlement reform is not the sort of bomb that we're thinking it is. In fact, when you talk about cutting spending or to preserve entitlements, Americans are strongly behind it. They're strongly behind constraining our budget and as well as reforming entitlements and that's good news.

CAVUTO: All right. My worry with this, Julie, is that we take at face value that anything that comes up there (INAUDIBLE) by that definition, on a fake show, in "Planet of the Apes". I guess the subliminal messages - we're not careful, this is us in just a few decades. I mean, we've got to get serious.

JULIE ROGINSKY, DEMOCRATIC PARTY STRATEGIST: You know why I'm so mad at you and your producers right now? I was sitting in my office minding my own business. They sent me this clip and they said, "Do you want to do the show today?" and you totally ruined the "House of Cards" for me. I was going to spend this weekend watching it and then you spoiled the whole thing. So--.

CAVUTO: I didn't give away how he - how he addresses this. I just--

ROGINSKY: I don't want to talk about it.

CAVUTO: --told you what one episode is about.

ROGINSKY: I have made people keep their mouths shut for a week and you ruined my day. Thank you very much. Look, I actually agree with you.

CAVUTO: You know it's fiction because it's a Democrats' series about a budget so you know it's fiction.

ROGINSKY: Yes. I forgot the last Democrat that actually gave us a balanced - oh, OK. (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Touche, young lady.

ROGINSKY: Yes, yes. Touche. His name was (INAUDIBLE). His name - his name was Bill Clinton, by the way.

CAVUTO: But even you, Julie - Julie, come on. Julie, even you - and I think Bill Clinton would take offense to everyone getting hyper about it.

ROGINSKY: I agree. Actually, I agree with you.

CAVUTO: You agree, right?

ROGINSKY: Totally. This is insane.

CAVUTO: All right. So Steve, she agrees. Democrats and Repubs are on the same page: "Everyone, lighten up." What say you?

MOORE: Well, look, first of all, I didn't even know Underwood was President so that's how far behind I am on this stuff. But - so thanks a lot. No, but look, here's the point. We know this. We have tens of trillions - that's trillions with a "T" - of unfunded liabilities in these programs. If we don't fix them, Neil, whether it's fictionally or in real life, we're going to end up - this country's going to end up like Detroit, in bankruptcy court.

CAVUTO: But even mentioning them on a fictitious show and what worries me- -.

MOORE: Well, that's the whole point.

SCHAEFFER: But again, you know--.

MOORE: But you know, Millennials like - Millennials do want to fix these programs.

CAVUTO: I agree. I agree. But I should (INAUDIBLE) to our audience that in "Dr. DoLittle", the animals do not really talk. I just want them to be aware of that. They do not really talk. Although some of them I think could if pushed.

ROGINSKY: I also don't think the President's killed two people with his own hands in the history of this country but I may be wrong about that. Frank Underwood's done a lot worse than (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: I don't know about that. I don't know about that.

ROGINSKY: I don't think he's pushed anybody from the D.C. metro anytime but I may be wrong about that.

SCHAEFFER: Let me add though that I don't think this is a political disaster either. I think that - I hope that people will take a look at the research that we did on this issue because it's not a lose-lose. It's a - there's a win politically and there's a win policy-wise. We have to deal with this issue because the pay-as-you-go system as Steve acknowledges is no longer working and--. But I think Americans are more behind reforming this. It's a matter of how do we talk about it in a way that makes people comfortable, it makes people realize that we're actually trying to preserve these systems for the future.

CAVUTO: All right. Well-said.

Guys, I want to thank you all. One other footnote to make - a lot of you who were confused whether the Linda Blair character in "Exorcist" was built on Nancy Pelosi. That one, you're right. That was in fact, the case.

Just lighten up, everyone. Lighten up.

Meanwhile, fake or real, it really doesn't matter because if these ladies are right, no one is serious about government spending at all, least of all, get this, Republicans.

To columnist Gina Loudon, Katherine Timf who say perish the thought.

What - Gina, what's going on here? Republicans are giving up the fight?

GINA LOUDON, CONSERVATIVE COLUMNIST: This is my question I really want to know how to answer. I speak around probably like you do to audiences of true patriots who elected this leadership and put them where they are and they are expecting some accountability. This is really what it comes down to. How do you answer the question? If Boehner was going to cave on this, Neil, why didn't he cave a week ago, just before that? Why didn't he - why did he wait until it was truly a war--.

CAVUTO: So you're angry (INAUDIBLE) dropped the ball again? 'Cause he did try their idea first and it fell through, right, (INAUDIBLE) the votes.

LOUDON: But when you - when you pit yourself against someone who you say, "This is a fight", and you lay down--. Let me ask you something. When's the last time they didn't lay down?

CAVUTO: I ask the questions around here, lady. What do you think this is? NetFlix?

LOUDON: When is the last time they didn't lay down? When is the last time you ever saw Boehner actually win a fight? When? I've never seen it.

CAVUTO: Well, now, Katherine, she's (INAUDIBLE) because whether you agree or disagree, there are quite a few like her who are not copacetic with the mainstream party and how it handles this stuff.

KATHERINE TIMPF, NATIONAL REVIEW COLUMNIST: Right. If you look at what he said towards the beginning, just like you said, he came out saying, "Watch out, Obama. You can't do this" and he can't. He actually can't. The executive order on the immigration--

CAVUTO: By the way, so did President Underwood. You know where that--.

TIMPF: --not able to do that. But the thing is even on a branding level, they're not doing a great job because right now, the Democrats are saying, "See how far the Republicans were willing to go because of how racist they are and they hate this immigration law." When really, it was about the fact that it's not constitutional. So there are so many issues here.

CAVUTO: Well, wait, I got no emails on that - that Republicans are racist- -.

TIMPF: If you look at liberal internet, they're saying, "See, they're so racist. They would let terrorists invade us and defunding the DHS" which, by the way, this is the only time I've ever heard them concerned about ISIS at all now that it's political.

CAVUTO: All of a sudden, they're concerned.

LOUDON: Right. Right.

CAVUTO: But Gina, I mean, your argument is we've got to be very close to understanding the threats that faces financial otherwise, and that Republicans have to be looking at that in their nominee whoever that is. If it were a Jeb Bush, if it were a Chris Christie, what would Gina Loudon do?

LOUDON: Well, I'll tell you, this administration has put us all in a mindset of we've got to have someone who isn't Barack Obama and certainly isn't Hillary or any of the selections that we're seeing come out of their camp. So we do - people in this country are worried about economic security and national security. That is number one on their mind that's paramount to the voters and that's not just conservatives. That is across the board when you talk (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But you don't like the guys I mentioned earlier?

LOUDON: I'm not - those aren't my number one choices. No. But I will say this - why instead - what has got to happen from the GOP and I still don't understand it is messaging, messaging, messaging and you alluded to this. You - why - instead of laying down again - didn't they just get on the messaging horse and just win this? The argument was so very simple and understandable for the average American and instead, they just kind of cower.

CAVUTO: Here's where I give them the benefit of the doubt. No, no. Here's where - I understand what you're saying but Katherine, they have to get through the mainstream media that will never cut them a break, that will call them - as you say - "racist", (INAUDIBLE) "You're going to shut down government" when we know in that case, that was never what this was going to be about. But they have to get through that. How do they?

TIMPF: They really do. Well, maybe they need to think about it before they go blazing saddles out with something like this. I don't know why they chose the DHS.

CAVUTO: By the way, blazing saddles was not a real (INAUDIBLE).

TIMPF: Yes. Yes. Wait, what?

CAVUTO: Was not a real event.

TIMPF: I have so many political opinions about it.

CAVUTO: The budget might be blazing but I digress.

TIMPF: But they came out and they weren't prepared to fight it to the end. And I don't know why they chose the DHS, like I was saying, rather than Department of Education. Of course DHS' mostly agencies that actually fight terrorism aren't even under that umbrella necessarily--.

CAVUTO: But that was interesting. Then all of a sudden, they were - the Democrats were concerned about terror.

TIMPF: All of a sudden, they're saying, "(INAUDIBLE) the DHS. But ISIS is going to invade us immediately if we even partially defund it."

CAVUTO: But Republicans dug themselves in that pit, didn't they?

TIMPF: Yes.

LOUDON: So all they had to say was "Look, this is 15 percent of employees who have mostly desk jobs." So somebody not playing Solitaire at their desk next week is not going affect Homeland Security. Let's be real about this.

CAVUTO: They're not all playing Solitaire. Some of them are on porn. Now, so, what do Republicans do right now? What's done is done, what's gone is gone?

TIMPF: It's humiliating. They need to find something that they all agree on and stand behind that and do it. 'Cause right now, they had this majority and it doesn't even matter because they can't agree on anything, it seems like. So they need to prove that they're powerful and not just reactive to everything.

CAVUTO: Gina?

LOUDON: I agree. They've got to stand. The Republicans have better - look at Reagan. He just stood and he convinced the country he was right. That's leadership. Look at (INAUDIBLE). He stands.

CAVUTO: But he also budged on - he raised taxes in 1986. They were still lower than they were when he took office but he was good at negotiating.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5FGV-SPV1-JB20-G454-00000-00Financial 'House of Cards'; Conservatives Concerned; Neil's Spiel: Cryin' Over Cuts; What The Tech?!; Target To Layoff Thousands; Are You Worried About Jobs?; FEMA: Sandy Fraud Rampant; Was Sandy Fraud Inevitable?; Obamacare Legal Limbo2015-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:49ZLexisNexisCAVUTO6:00 PM ESTSteve Moore, Sabrina Schaeffer, Julie Roginsky, Gina Loudon, Katherine Timf, Dan Mitchell, Christina Warren, Craig Smith, Michael Brown, Jared LevyNEWSBusiness030401cb.223Financial 'House of Cards'; Conservatives Concerned; Neil's Spiel: Cryin' Over Cuts; What The Tech?!; Target To Layoff Thousands; Are You Worried About Jobs?; FEMA: Sandy Fraud Rampant; Was Sandy Fraud Inevitable?; Obamacare Legal LimboNeil Cavuto, Maria Bartiromo, Elizabeth Macdonald

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: Here's why I fear we will never ever, ever get entitlement spending under control. Forget about ever really doing it, we can't even fake doing it.

Welcome, everyone. Glad to have you. I'm Neil Cavuto.

And talk about a "House of Cards", literally, because the fictional president on that fictional NetFlix show takes a fictional stab at entitlement spending and liberal blogs are going seriously nuts. But even more seriously nuts when I bring up the ridiculous reaction to this utterly ridiculous, totally made-up issue.

Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP - "YOUR WORLD", YESTERDAY)

CAVUTO: The Huffington Post detailing how Underwood's goal of zero unemployment is impossible and that even if he did get there, inflation would get out of control everywhere.

This tell you all you need to know, that even cutting entitlements on a fake show with a fake president gets this type of real irate response. This is Rome in the final days.

(END VIDEO CLIP - "YOUR WORLD", YESTERDAY)

CAVUTO: Now, you can almost guess what happens next - angry Liberals jumping on moi for them jumping on this.

This headline on a very popular media website summed it up. "Fox's Cavuto Proudly Stands with the President (No, Not Obama)". The writer goes on to explain that I was seriously rushing to a fake President Underwood's defense.

Newsflash! I wasn't rushing to anyone's defense, just wondering why so many were taking offense over something that wasn't real and a President and a whole storyline that are totally made-up. It didn't matter. I was just seriously evil.

I want you to take a look at just some of the responses.

Like this one: "Figures Cavuto loves Frank Underwood more than Barack Obama..."

Then this: "Fake President for a fake news channel."

This one I personally like: "Pravda and Tass are models for Fox News."

And then this one: "Cavuto's a troll and a midget ogre." I have no idea what that means.

"Obviously, Cavuto's OK letting our poor suffer. He makes Underwood look like Lincoln."

Then this: "What a heartless bastard this fat Fox fake is... all for cutting entitlements any way he can." Who are you calling "fat"?

Anyway, "Most people are aware that Repubs suffer Schizophrenia..", I forgot, "..mixed with racism...", I forgot that too, "...it's a dangerous combo."

Then this: "Underwood's cut to entitlements fund a $500 billion stimulus program. Cavuto didn't mention that."

Well, actually, I did mention that but who needs facts on something that's fake and thank God for at least some viewers who did know what I was getting at.

Like this guy: "This headline is so deceptive. The Fox host was ranting about a fictional character being taken seriously by left-wing websites and somehow he is defending him? This website is growing worse day by day."

Now, there were a lot of other emails like that last one. In fact, most emails were like that last one. But my point here wasn't to make me look good. I don't have to.

Anyway, my other point though was to quite seriously take a look at how difficult it is to ever get a handle on real entitlement reform because even when we're discussing a fake show, my God, we can't even fake it. And if that's the case, we really are a financial 'House of Cards'.

To political watcher Steve Moore, Sabrina Schaeffer, Julie Roginsky.

Steve, what do you think?

STEVE MOORE, HERITAGE FOUNDATION CHIEF ECONOMIST: Well, Neil, it is a (INAUDIBLE) fake character and it is a fake show. But you know what? It's not a fake crisis. This entitlement time bomb that is (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: You're feeding the beast, Moore. You're feeding the beast.

MOORE: Well, you had it exactly right. This is a real crisis. Ten thousand Americans are retiring every day. They're going on Medicare. They're going on social security. This is the Titanic headed right towards the iceberg. And shame on you for saying maybe we should start turning that ship away from the iceberg. But you're right on.

CAVUTO: But here's the thing, Sabrina. I mean, even when a fake show lobs this up, silly as it was, it gets this type of reaction. People are seriously all worked-up about it. So Sabrina, my worry with this is if we can't even get to it on a fake entitlement address, how are we ever going to get serious about it?

SABRINA SCHAEFFER, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S FORUM: Well, here's the thing, Neil, and this is where the writers got Frank Underwood totally wrong. Democrats would never have released something like Frank Underwood does on this AmWorks program without intensive persuasion messaging research. Frank Underwood would never have just talked about entitlement reform the way he did in that meeting in that scene in the show. In fact, the Independent Women's Forum did conduct a randomized controlled experiment to figure out how do we talk about it and talking about entitlement reform is not the sort of bomb that we're thinking it is. In fact, when you talk about cutting spending or to preserve entitlements, Americans are strongly behind it. They're strongly behind constraining our budget and as well as reforming entitlements and that's good news.

CAVUTO: All right. My worry with this, Julie, is that we take at face value that anything that comes up there (INAUDIBLE) by that definition, on a fake show, in "Planet of the Apes". I guess the subliminal messages - we're not careful, this is us in just a few decades. I mean, we've got to get serious.

JULIE ROGINSKY, DEMOCRATIC PARTY STRATEGIST: You know why I'm so mad at you and your producers right now? I was sitting in my office minding my own business. They sent me this clip and they said, "Do you want to do the show today?" and you totally ruined the "House of Cards" for me. I was going to spend this weekend watching it and then you spoiled the whole thing. So--.

CAVUTO: I didn't give away how he - how he addresses this. I just--

ROGINSKY: I don't want to talk about it.

CAVUTO: --told you what one episode is about.

ROGINSKY: I have made people keep their mouths shut for a week and you ruined my day. Thank you very much. Look, I actually agree with you.

CAVUTO: You know it's fiction because it's a Democrats' series about a budget so you know it's fiction.

ROGINSKY: Yes. I forgot the last Democrat that actually gave us a balanced - oh, OK. (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Touche, young lady.

ROGINSKY: Yes, yes. Touche. His name was (INAUDIBLE). His name - his name was Bill Clinton, by the way.

CAVUTO: But even you, Julie - Julie, come on. Julie, even you - and I think Bill Clinton would take offense to everyone getting hyper about it.

ROGINSKY: I agree. Actually, I agree with you.

CAVUTO: You agree, right?

ROGINSKY: Totally. This is insane.

CAVUTO: All right. So Steve, she agrees. Democrats and Repubs are on the same page: "Everyone, lighten up." What say you?

MOORE: Well, look, first of all, I didn't even know Underwood was President so that's how far behind I am on this stuff. But - so thanks a lot. No, but look, here's the point. We know this. We have tens of trillions - that's trillions with a "T" - of unfunded liabilities in these programs. If we don't fix them, Neil, whether it's fictionally or in real life, we're going to end up - this country's going to end up like Detroit, in bankruptcy court.

CAVUTO: But even mentioning them on a fictitious show and what worries me- -.

MOORE: Well, that's the whole point.

SCHAEFFER: But again, you know--.

MOORE: But you know, Millennials like - Millennials do want to fix these programs.

CAVUTO: I agree. I agree. But I should (INAUDIBLE) to our audience that in "Dr. DoLittle", the animals do not really talk. I just want them to be aware of that. They do not really talk. Although some of them I think could if pushed.

ROGINSKY: I also don't think the President's killed two people with his own hands in the history of this country but I may be wrong about that. Frank Underwood's done a lot worse than (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: I don't know about that. I don't know about that.

ROGINSKY: I don't think he's pushed anybody from the D.C. metro anytime but I may be wrong about that.

SCHAEFFER: Let me add though that I don't think this is a political disaster either. I think that - I hope that people will take a look at the research that we did on this issue because it's not a lose-lose. It's a - there's a win politically and there's a win policy-wise. We have to deal with this issue because the pay-as-you-go system as Steve acknowledges is no longer working and--. But I think Americans are more behind reforming this. It's a matter of how do we talk about it in a way that makes people comfortable, it makes people realize that we're actually trying to preserve these systems for the future.

CAVUTO: All right. Well-said.

Guys, I want to thank you all. One other footnote to make - a lot of you who were confused whether the Linda Blair character in "Exorcist" was built on Nancy Pelosi. That one, you're right. That was in fact, the case.

Just lighten up, everyone. Lighten up.

Meanwhile, fake or real, it really doesn't matter because if these ladies are right, no one is serious about government spending at all, least of all, get this, Republicans.

To columnist Gina Loudon, Katherine Timf who say perish the thought.

What - Gina, what's going on here? Republicans are giving up the fight?

GINA LOUDON, CONSERVATIVE COLUMNIST: This is my question I really want to know how to answer. I speak around probably like you do to audiences of true patriots who elected this leadership and put them where they are and they are expecting some accountability. This is really what it comes down to. How do you answer the question? If Boehner was going to cave on this, Neil, why didn't he cave a week ago, just before that? Why didn't he - why did he wait until it was truly a war--.

CAVUTO: So you're angry (INAUDIBLE) dropped the ball again? 'Cause he did try their idea first and it fell through, right, (INAUDIBLE) the votes.

LOUDON: But when you - when you pit yourself against someone who you say, "This is a fight", and you lay down--. Let me ask you something. When's the last time they didn't lay down?

CAVUTO: I ask the questions around here, lady. What do you think this is? NetFlix?

LOUDON: When is the last time they didn't lay down? When is the last time you ever saw Boehner actually win a fight? When? I've never seen it.

CAVUTO: Well, now, Katherine, she's (INAUDIBLE) because whether you agree or disagree, there are quite a few like her who are not copacetic with the mainstream party and how it handles this stuff.

KATHERINE TIMPF, NATIONAL REVIEW COLUMNIST: Right. If you look at what he said towards the beginning, just like you said, he came out saying, "Watch out, Obama. You can't do this" and he can't. He actually can't. The executive order on the immigration--

CAVUTO: By the way, so did President Underwood. You know where that--.

TIMPF: --not able to do that. But the thing is even on a branding level, they're not doing a great job because right now, the Democrats are saying, "See how far the Republicans were willing to go because of how racist they are and they hate this immigration law." When really, it was about the fact that it's not constitutional. So there are so many issues here.

CAVUTO: Well, wait, I got no emails on that - that Republicans are racist- -.

TIMPF: If you look at liberal internet, they're saying, "See, they're so racist. They would let terrorists invade us and defunding the DHS" which, by the way, this is the only time I've ever heard them concerned about ISIS at all now that it's political.

CAVUTO: All of a sudden, they're concerned.

LOUDON: Right. Right.

CAVUTO: But Gina, I mean, your argument is we've got to be very close to understanding the threats that faces financial otherwise, and that Republicans have to be looking at that in their nominee whoever that is. If it were a Jeb Bush, if it were a Chris Christie, what would Gina Loudon do?

LOUDON: Well, I'll tell you, this administration has put us all in a mindset of we've got to have someone who isn't Barack Obama and certainly isn't Hillary or any of the selections that we're seeing come out of their camp. So we do - people in this country are worried about economic security and national security. That is number one on their mind that's paramount to the voters and that's not just conservatives. That is across the board when you talk (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: But you don't like the guys I mentioned earlier?

LOUDON: I'm not - those aren't my number one choices. No. But I will say this - why instead - what has got to happen from the GOP and I still don't understand it is messaging, messaging, messaging and you alluded to this. You - why - instead of laying down again - didn't they just get on the messaging horse and just win this? The argument was so very simple and understandable for the average American and instead, they just kind of cower.

CAVUTO: Here's where I give them the benefit of the doubt. No, no. Here's where - I understand what you're saying but Katherine, they have to get through the mainstream media that will never cut them a break, that will call them - as you say - "racist", (INAUDIBLE) "You're going to shut down government" when we know in that case, that was never what this was going to be about. But they have to get through that. How do they?

TIMPF: They really do. Well, maybe they need to think about it before they go blazing saddles out with something like this. I don't know why they chose the DHS.

CAVUTO: By the way, blazing saddles was not a real (INAUDIBLE).

TIMPF: Yes. Yes. Wait, what?

CAVUTO: Was not a real event.

TIMPF: I have so many political opinions about it.

CAVUTO: The budget might be blazing but I digress.

TIMPF: But they came out and they weren't prepared to fight it to the end. And I don't know why they chose the DHS, like I was saying, rather than Department of Education. Of course DHS' mostly agencies that actually fight terrorism aren't even under that umbrella necessarily--.

CAVUTO: But that was interesting. Then all of a sudden, they were - the Democrats were concerned about terror.

TIMPF: All of a sudden, they're saying, "(INAUDIBLE) the DHS. But ISIS is going to invade us immediately if we even partially defund it."

CAVUTO: But Republicans dug themselves in that pit, didn't they?

TIMPF: Yes.

LOUDON: So all they had to say was "Look, this is 15 percent of employees who have mostly desk jobs." So somebody not playing Solitaire at their desk next week is not going affect Homeland Security. Let's be real about this.

CAVUTO: They're not all playing Solitaire. Some of them are on porn. Now, so, what do Republicans do right now? What's done is done, what's gone is gone?

TIMPF: It's humiliating. They need to find something that they all agree on and stand behind that and do it. 'Cause right now, they had this majority and it doesn't even matter because they can't agree on anything, it seems like. So they need to prove that they're powerful and not just reactive to everything.

CAVUTO: Gina?

LOUDON: I agree. They've got to stand. The Republicans have better - look at Reagan. He just stood and he convinced the country he was right. That's leadership. Look at (INAUDIBLE). He stands.

CAVUTO: But he also budged on - he raised taxes in 1986. They were still lower than they were when he took office but he was good at negotiating.

LOUDON: He was big at leading. People need a leader in this country. We are - we are looking at all the threats - North Korea, of course, Iran, so on and so forth, and we're watching as other leaders around the country lead and the leaders in this country including the Republican leaders right now are refusing to lead. They're making commitments. They're making strong stands. And then they're backing down or they're just cowering to start. It's a very scary place to be right now.

CAVUTO: So you're saying that a guy who started as an actor in movies was in fact a real leader?

LOUDON: He was in fact a real leader.

CAVUTO: Take that, Underwood.

LOUDON: That brings it full circle.

CAVUTO: I know we're going to get emails on this show. People, lighten up!

All right. In the meantime, the IRS is singing the budget blues. Now, who exactly is singing yours?

CAVUTO: Talk about taxing and the IRS complaining. Now, well, you've already heard how the agency's been whining about budget cuts that has supposedly compromised its ability to audit you. But now, the Treasury's chiming in to say those same cuts are going to create even more headaches for you. They might not be able to get refunds out as fast or administer the financial part of the health care law that's their responsibility as well.

Well, compared to what? Is it me or is the government more concerned about - well - its own tax headaches than your tax headaches, your burdens, your rules to which you better comply, your myriad of new tax forms that you better fill out. Never mind you're overwhelmed, the Treasury Secretary says it's a bigger deal because they are?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP - WASHINGTON, DC, YESTERDAY)

JACK LEW, TREASURY SECRETARY: A sustained deterioration in taxpayer service combined with reduced enforcement activity presents serious long- term risks for the U.S. tax system.

(END VIDEO CLIP - WASHINGTON, DC, YESTERDAY)

CAVUTO: No, he did not play the role of the quiet man. That was John Wayne. That's Treasury Secretary Lew.

Anyway, forget the long-term risks for the U.S. tax system. CATO tax policy analyst Dan Mitchell worries more about the long-term risks for the U.S. taxpayer.

Dan, I think they've got it (INAUDIBLE) backwards here but fill me in on what you think.

DAN MITCHELL, CATO TAX POLICY ANALYST: If you look at the IRS budget numbers over the last 30 years, you'll see that even after adjusting for inflation, the IRS has almost twice as big of a budget now as they did 30 years ago. Now, it's not as high as the peak in 2010 when all the fake stimulus money was being thrown around in Washington and every agency was drowning in taxpayer money there, their budgets were so blown-up. But the notion that we should feel sorry for the IRS and somehow we're not going to get the right service from the IRS reminds me of the country boys I knew in college who talked about bulls servicing cows. Hey, if the IRS leaves us alone, I'll be perfectly happy.

CAVUTO: Careful, there's a movie about that too but I'll think of it - "Deliverance". (INAUDIBLE). Here's what worries me, Dan, that what they're trying to say is if you're not getting this or you're waiting for this, they're telegraphing it, they're doing some pre-hiney-covering and that worries me too. What else aren't they saying? Or what else potentially are they bracing us for?

MITCHELL: The IRS has almost a 100,000 employees. As I've said, their budget is almost twice as big adjusted for inflation as it was 30 years ago. The notion that they're claiming that they somehow can't competently enforce the tax code? Well, maybe if they didn't spend so much money participating in an illegal rewrite of the Obamacare law, maybe if they weren't trying to influence American elections by political biased approval of different nonprofit groups, maybe if they just focused on their core mission, they would have plenty of money to enforce the tax code. And I say this as someone who doesn't necessarily blame the IRS because it's the politicians that have given us the 76.000-page tax code and that of course is a burden, not just on us but the IRS doesn't know how to enforce that either.

CAVUTO: By the way, if any of you at the IRS are watching this segment right now, Dan is the one saying all of these horrible stuff. I think you're just doing a fine job myself. But Dan, here's another thing that kind of interests me on all of this. To be fair to the IRS, they have the financial burden of doing a lot of the financial part of the health care law. Now, I thought we hired 60,000 IRS agents to do this and that that was going to be enough to cover it. It seems to me that Treasury Secretary Lew who was not John Wayne in "The Quiet Man" - just so people at home would know - understand that might not be enough or what?

MITCHELL: We definitely have one of these - what - immovable objects, irresistible force conflicts because the tax code is such a mess and because things like Obamacare are now supposed to be enforced by the IRS, we have to fundamentally choose. Do we either basically give massive power and massive (INAUDIBLE) budgets to the IRS and basically let them tell us how to live our lives? Or do we basically resist and tell the politicians, "No, we've had enough"? We don't like the fact that our lives are being looked into. We don't like the fact that we have no privacy. We don't like the fact that we give up our constitutional presumption of innocence when dealing with the IRS. Maybe you guys in Washington on Capitol Hill and the White House need to fix some of the mess in the tax code. As far as I'm concerned, I would much rather force them to change the tax code than to simply give more money to the IRS to try to prop up a system that - if we leave it on autopilot, we're going to wind up being Greece.

CAVUTO: All right, Dan. Thank you very much. For those who don't know at home, Dan was the inspiration for "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington."

In the meantime, still calling them Blackburied? "What the Tech?!", someone forgot to tell Blackberry.

CAVUTO: Blackberry is branching out. Ford is biking out. And Dominos and Pizza Hut with gizmos to help you order out. We're here to figure them all out on the hottest new segment in all of cable news because "What the Tech?!" is here and all of your tech questions are answered each night, every night. If it's a digit, dig it, we are all over it.

I kind of like that.

Anyway, long before folks were even talking about it, so hip, so happening, so me, we've already patented the name.

Now, to tonight's big tech issues.

First up, Blackberry. Given up for dead but it is still not giving up. The company offering not one, not two, not three, but four new devices aimed at the corporate and government crowd. Sure, they've lost customers but the only ones they still have are rabidly loyal and when it comes to these raised keyboards, obsessively so.

So what does Mashable's Christina Warren make all of this? Before we get to her, I just want to confirm for all of you, it was not a Blackberry device that was an inspiration in "Fast Times in Ridgemont High." All right? We all clear on that? Very close. Phone - yes, they did have a phone-in order pizza but it was not via Blackberry.

OK. What do you make of this?

CHRISTINA WARREN, MASHABLE SENIOR TECH ANALYST: It's not a bad move on Blackberry's part. They're coming out with four new devices. One of them is actually going to be a slider that actually has a keyboard that slides out.

CAVUTO: Physical keyboard (INAUDIBLE)?

WARREN: It will still have (INAUDIBLE) keyboard.

CAVUTO: Is that (INAUDIBLE) what Blackberry (INAUDIBLE)?

WARREN: It is not. One other new device is called the "Leap" that they announced this week is actually a full touch device and it's going to be fairly low-cost. They're kind of aiming it at the - I guess - early enterprise market kind of--.

CAVUTO: Would your generation buy that?

WARREN: No.

CAVUTO: Why not? You think they've come and gone?

WARREN: They have. They're not there with the apps. But you know what? They still have a really strong business presence. They're still really known for security. So I think what they're really doing which is smart is they're expanding into being more of a software company. So they're starting to put their software on other products including Android and iOS. And I think that's really their big growth of opportunity. Devices not so much. Like you said, there's still the loyalists, still the people who love them and won't ever give them up.

CAVUTO: Oh, I know.

WARREN: But--

CAVUTO: They're out there.

WARREN: They are out there. But for everybody else has moved on.

CAVUTO: All right. This next story was indeed the inspiration for "Fast Times in Ridgemont High". This was the one you've got to watch because are you interested in ordering a slice on a smartwatch? Well, Dominos is testing it. Rival Pizza Hut testing something very similar but not on a watch, on a special device in your car.

Christina, what the tech? What is this? Are we in that much of a rush?

WARREN: For pizza? Yes. And there's also a new magnet that you put on your fridge and you literally press a button, it orders you pizza.

CAVUTO: Oh, sign me up.

WARREN: No. See, this sounds silly at first, right? Like, do we really need pizza any faster?

CAVUTO: Not at all. Not to me.

WARREN: But if you think about it, OK. So take it away from pizza and say, maybe, have laundry pick-up or maybe I can have take-out order or maybe my groceries can be ordered for me. We're getting into the age of (INAUDIBLE).

CAVUTO: Yes. But what if you have kids that keep hitting (INAUDIBLE).

WARREN: That's a good point. That's a good point. It needs security. But we're kind of reaching this age where everything can be automated and customized in such a way that we can do one-touch ordering and it can be delivered the way you want it, when you want it, wherever.

CAVUTO: All right. The kid reference was a reference to "Home Alone" and "Home Alone 2".

Meanwhile, what the tech?! Ford is peddling bicycles with apparently not just any bicycles, the automaker - at least the last time I checked - is creating a new e-bicycle with navigation sensors. The thing even folds up.

Christina, does this have like just "steal me" written all over it?

WARREN: It does. It does. But it also has - for me, I'm like "I want to ride this" because this looks amazing. They're taking the best of--.

CAVUTO: Well, why are they doing it?

WARREN: Well, a lot of people are not driving these days especially a lot of young people. They look at studies, people are getting their licenses older and people are not getting into cars as much.

CAVUTO: This is (INAUDIBLE) people are going to - would you ride this?

WARREN: You know what? I might. Especially that folds up. Say I can use it for GPS navigation with my phone. It can help me pedal if it gets too hard especially when the weather's nicer. Right now, I wouldn't ride a bike.

CAVUTO: (INAUDIBLE). You know? So Ford seems to be covering its (INAUDIBLE). What I noticed in all the pictures they show of it, they have it in a car.

WARREN: Yes.

CAVUTO: Which I like here it is in a car.

WARREN: Well, they're saying you drive to the bike track and then you bike around but (INAUDIBLE) you can just bike.

CAVUTO: All right. So you think this (INAUDIBLE) that others might follow suit because Google wants to do cars, Ford that does cars wants to do bikes. It just seems weird.

WARREN: I think they're just trying to kind of cover all their bases. They know that a lot of people especially in urban areas are trying to be more green and are walking more, biking more so why not get into that market while they can?

CAVUTO: All right. Thank you.

This is not from a clip the Andromeda Strain. Very close. Remember, he blew up a bike but it was not that bike. And it was certainly not Arnold Schwarzenegger.

All right. Now, we know you weren't spending that gas money you were saving. And unfortunately, so do the folks at Target.

CAVUTO: We are still wondering, but enough about me. Imagine inheriting a thermometer from your parents. You just throw it right out, right? Now imagine that thermometer is 134 years old. It would be harder to get rid of that. Find out what family does with his landmark on "STRANGE INHERITANCE."

Meanwhile, expect more and pay less, just don't expect help getting that giant bag of toilet paper off the top shelf because Target is planning to cut thousands of its jobs. It's not alone, companies big and small, planning layoffs.

Market watcher, Craig Smith, who was indeed the inspiration for the captain on the "Titanic," in the movie "The Titanic" joins right now. All right, so Craig, what is going on here because a lot of these guys seemed to be repeating the same story.

CRAIG SMITH, "DON'T BANK ON IT" AUTHOR: Isn't that the truth, brick-and- mortar has got some lessons to learn here, Neil, as they walk down through the graveyard JC Penney, Kmart, Sears and Radioshack.

CAVUTO: But I thought consumers were coming back and you were the first to warn, wait a minute, let's not party too soon here.

CRAIG: Well, yes, and the reason I did not is because the economy hasn't turned around, Neil. Look, I mean, Brian Cornell has his work cut out for him. He is laying off some people, but watch what he is going to do like $2 billion worth of stock back increasing his stock price, creating better dividends.

I mean, Neil, from Q1 one of 2009 to the last numbers we have, the third quarter of 2014, S&P corporations have bought back $2.1 trillion worth of stocks, Neil --

CAVUTO: What does that mean?

SMITH: It means that they are showing great profits because of what they are doing on their balance sheets, but not because they are bringing more people in the stores, not because people are spending more money, and not because they are making more money.

They are basically doing it by balance sheet corrections. Neil, we cannot see these corporations make big money when we are growing an economy at 2 percent, Neil. It doesn't work.

CAVUTO: So I'm beginning to wonder and we've seen in income and spending numbers. Income up a little bit and spending down a little bit. This has been a trend of like where consumers, whatever savings they are getting and we will be exploring this a little bit more in the show, they are just not spending it and I wonder whether they see something.

SMITH: That's an interesting question and I will have to speculate. But Neil, we know for a fact that every penny at the pump means a billion dollars in the economy. We have seen at least $100 billion in gas prices coming into this economy. Where did it go?

We don't see anybody ripping the cover off the ball other than Apple, which by the way, if my watch goes off, I have a piece on order -- but it's amazing because you know as well as I do and Fox Business has done a great job covering this.

The underlying economy is not growing at the pace that we need to hold these corporate profits were they are. That is why corporations are buying back their stock. Think about it, if your corporate bond rate is at historic low, 3.8 percent return, your forward earnings are 5.8 percent.

And your CEO, you buy your stock back. You make your stock go up. You pay more money in dividends to your shareholders --

CAVUTO: No, Craig, you are absolutely right. But here is the flip side why people kind of like this perverse as it sounds that in this environment there is no way the Federal Reserve will hike rates. You will still be able to play this game where you borrow low and buy whatever and that this will kind of keep this slow-moving puppy going. What do you think?

SMITH: If --

CAVUTO: You're right.

SMITH: If investors don't start looking at other markets that are now starting to use QE to do the same thing because if you see Europe do this, you're going to see a bunch of money leave America and go to Europe looking for the same return --

CAVUTO: So does that hit the Nasdaq as well? A lot of people have been saying that's a tech bubble there.

SMITH: Well, I'm not sure it's a tech bubble because this time they have earnings. You know, before the last tech bubble, companies open up. They never had any earnings or any profits and went from zero to $200 per share.

But Neil, we don't have the underlying economic strength to support this and that is why I wish Mr. Barack Obama would get out of the way and let free enterprise work. I really do.

CAVUTO: All right, Craig, good seeing you again.

SMITH: Good seeing you, Neil.

CAVUTO: Great info. Craig Smith, the Swiss America Trading Corp chairman, as I said, the inspiration for the captain in "The Titanic."

All right, well, more than two years after Sandy, all the money that never made it to the victims. Now we know. Don't say that I didn't warn you then. Several Republican lawmakers want to wait until they know exactly where each dollar is going.

Now before you start saying this sounds cruel and awful, think of all the money we have wasted not tracking it, the money that went to Haiti to help them out and that never really help them out, the money that went post- Katrina that never helped anyone out in Louisiana.

You know, I hate to say it, but this is a one-time I wish that I was wrong.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOVERNOR CHRIS CHRISTIE (R), NEW JERSEY: There is only one group to blame for the continued suffering of these innocent victims, the House Majority and their Speaker John Boehner.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Governor Chris Christie was not the inspiration for "Godzilla," just a point of reference, although the movie was twice a hit, back then the governor wasn't exactly feeling the love for the guy he said was holding up all of that dough.

Now a lot of folks are asking what really was the rush, a top FEMA official now admitting government-backed insurers have been fudging data to deny flood insurance settlements, and even knew about it for over a year, and they dare castigated this guy? Michael Brown not at all surprised. Michael, what do you make of this?

MICHAEL BROWN, FORMER FEMA DIRECTOR: Neil, you have heard of crony capitalism, ask yourself a simple question, why do we have flood insurance that's subsidized and paid for by the taxpayers? Why do we not have tornado insurance, hurricane insurance, ice storm insurance, thunderstorm insurance?

It's because the insurance companies somehow convinced Congress decades ago that they didn't want to deal with the actuarial problems and the repetitive claims you had the flood insurance so they pond that off onto FEMA.

And so now you have a program that for decades even while I was at FEMA was problematic. It's not actuarially sound. Congress is always interfering and telling people you should pay these claims or you can't charge this premium. It is a perfect example of a program that should be in the private sector and the government shouldn't have its hands anywhere near it.

CAVUTO: So what was FEMA's role in this? Is it mistaken, deliberate, just dumb, what?

BROWN: Yes, all of the above. I think there's probably everything going on, Neil. I think there are probably some folks that work in the National Flood Insurance Program where these kinds of fraudulent claims just went passed them. They just didn't notice it.

You may have some people within FEMA who deliberately were in cahoots with some of these engineering companies and insurance companies. And then you have the leadership who goes on another program and says to themselves, I've been here three weeks and this is something that should have been brought to us.

Well, that is a systemic problem within the government when you have those kinds of programs. It just shouldn't be in the government in the first place.

CAVUTO: All right, but we know either directly or indirectly through FEMA and all of these other federal sources, $60 billion was allocated to deal with Sandy.

And you know, talking to friends and those who were affected in Statin Island, much of New Jersey, I'm not saying that none of them got it, but not nearly the number you would think. There are people to this day, Mike, still waiting for this stuff. What does that say?

BROWN: It says that government is inherently incapable of doing what Americans for I think the wrong reasons have come to expect the government to do and that's to come in and rebuild their lives for them.

Look, I have the deepest sympathy for people whose lives are upended by Mother Nature or a man-made disaster, but at the end of the day, people have to recognize that government isn't going to be the answer.

The answer is going to be to make sure you have your own insurance, to make sure that you are prepared for those disasters and make sure that you can recover from them as quickly as possible and if you're waiting on somebody inside the beltway to take care of you, you're just being foolish.

CAVUTO: I'm still waiting for Governor Christie or now Governor Cuomo, and these others to come out and simply say we were wrong. I'd love to hear that.

BROWN: Neil, you know, we're close to the ten-year anniversary of Katrina and there are still problems there in New Orleans so you know, welcome to the club.

CAVUTO: Yes, but I'll tell you what? I know I told you this before, Michael, they jumped to point the finger at you. Something far more egregious what happened here. No one says boo. That is ridiculous.

BROWN: Yes, it is.

CAVUTO: Michael Brown, thank you very, very so much, the former FEMA director. Who, if you want to know the accurate story, warned about everything that ultimately did happen with Katrina.

Anyway, the Supreme Court is taking up Obamacare again. The media says this is another conservative attack. So then why are doctors and patients scrambling to fend off a premium attack?

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS: I'm Maria Bartiromo. Actress and producer, Goldie Hawn on equal pay in Hollywood and how it is blocking some movies from being made. OPENING BELL at 9 a.m. Eastern right here on the Fox Business Network.

CAVUTO: In tonight's Biz Blitz. Obamacare take "D," the Supreme Court once again taking off an argument that cuts to the Affordable Care Act's core, those subsidies that help folks buy it.

Do the justices buy it or will they rule that any subsidy violates the constitution and just junk it or throw it in Congress' lap. Remember it's those subsidies that get people in so what happens if that carrot goes?

That is pretty much at the heart of Republicans arguments and why they took it to the high court. To Jared Levy and Lizzie Macdonald, why a ruling in their favor could actually put Republicans in a very sticky position, Lizzie, what do you think?

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS: You know, I'll tell you something. No less than nine times in the Affordable Care Act does it say that the tax breaks or credits were meant for states that built their own exchanges, period. That's what it says.

It did not say the IRS is allowed to define the law after the fact and make up rules and regulations ad hoc after-the-fact. And I'll tell you something, even though they are saying chaos, the world is going to hell in a handbasket, you can get catastrophic insurance interim if this law falls apart at the Supreme Court level.

CAVUTO: All right, now let's say that these are unconstitutional, what do Republicans do because it would be thrown back in their lap? All right, that's a find mess you got us into. Premiums are soaring. Costs are soaring and it's all because you guys are protesting. What do you think, Jared?

JARED LEVY, PROFITABLE TRADING.COM SENIOR STRATEGIST: It's funny. It is a really selfish choice when you think about it because on one hand, yes, you have this act, which is now putting insurance companies in control of the ways that we get treated as patients, personally, professionally, I've experienced nothing but bad things.

But you're right. If Republicans do over throw this, if we do breakdown the subsidies in 34 states and if people don't get their subsidies, you got 7.5 million people who aren't voting for a GOP candidate next election. That's a guarantee just about so again I'd like to see it repealed, but it does hurt the GOP if indeed that does happen.

CAVUTO: Al right, Jared was quoting Sophie's choice, but this was actually inspiration for the movie "The Scarlet Letter." Meanwhile, something to cushion a fired CEO, McDonald's is paying its ousted boss, Don Thompson, $3 million as a consultant, which is about three times more than the salary of his successor.

It's true. While the new guy is still a 69 percent pay, the salary part of that is 1.1 million, he gets things cooking, he could be getting another $1 million to $1.5 million incentive, but Lizzie, that is still not equal to the pay of the guy that he replaced.

MACDONALD: Yes, this is quite a happy meal that McDonald's is giving its exiting CEO. The golden arch is giving quite a golden parachute to a guy who oversaw a sales slide in the U.S. but less is less, and now two years, he is a consultant.

And lo and behold, you just saw the other news that McDonald's is finally saying that we are going to take antibiotics out of our meat products. Well, guess, what Panero Bread and Chipotle already did that.

You know, I mentioned, Chipotle, McDonald's should never spun it off. It's now worth a fifth of its entire market cap -- so I don't know what's going on here. I don't why you pay the guy more money who didn't really do such a great job improving McDonald's.

CAVUTO: By the way, we keep referencing movies here and while this guy is going to remain a consultant of McDonald's, I was, everything is going to be disclosed here and consulted. Jared, what do you think of this?

LEVY: All right, so first of all, Thompson was there for 25 years so I think he's staying on as a consultant as an exit strategy is smart. Paying him $3 million not so much, but it's interesting though, you look at from a stock perspective.

The stocks knocking on new 52-week highs and while that is a lot of the way that we measure this, I think a lot of it is just a happy meal that investors should be given. There is a lot of hope here that this new CEO, Easterbrook, is going to change things.

So we have to talk about this from this perspective. I do not think that McDonald's is a smart bet right now. I think that it moves lower before it continues back on its meteoric rise.

CAVUTO: All right, onto issue three here, guys, after talking millions and saving pennies, we have been getting it. Those pennies that Americans were saving with the lower gas prices are not translating into a billion-dollar boon for corporations, more like a hit, a bad hit.

We are telling you how Target is laying off folks. It's a clear sign customers are not spending it. Apparently, they are worried about savings accounts. What's got them worried, Lizzie?

MACDONALD: Well, you know, what's got them worried, there are other analysts out there, debt and record levels near the $12 trillion that never really came down. They are worried about, you know, health care costs going up so according to the conference board just a fifth of the consumers are going out to retail stores to buy things, doing things like paying their debt and sucking it away for health care.

CAVUTO: The customers still looks pretty wobbly to me, Jared, should we worry?

LEVY: I don't know about worry all around. I think we need to do is dissect this a little bit deeper. First of all, "Consumer Reports" came out with a great report, great story about how consumers habits of change.

They are buying bigger stuff. They are buying cars, washing machines, stuff that's fixed. They are not buying a lot of little trinket and stuff like Target may sell, right?

So maybe look to sort of big appliance companies from an investment perspective, but watch some of the retailers that cater to some of the more frivolous if you will.

CAVUTO: Well, where are they going, dollar store, and these kinds of cheap alternatives?

MACDONALD: It seems that way and they are buying -- Jared is right. They are buying groceries. They are not to the retailers or certainly the luxury retailers. And you know what, they are kind of buying cars, but they are definitely not going to the mall to the department stores.

CAVUTO: Jared, if that keeps up, though, the theory is that you -- the big items that you could buy, but eventually that well runs dry.

LEVY: There is a compounding problem there, right, as the dollar rises, all of the Europeans and Asians coming are spending their money on the high-end products, now we have the double effect and so I think that yes, potentially, we could see this move lower in a lot of the high-end retailers. So this is a sector by sector thing and I don't think it will cause an economic crisis anytime soon.

CAVUTO: All right, guys, I want to thank you both very much.

In the meantime, take a look at this, it's an Apple spaceship. I want you to find out which tech companies are giving Apple a ship?

CAVUTO: To a tech takeover, if you are impressed with Apple spaceship campus, get a load of Google's plans for a tented city, a fully functional headquarters complete with running tracks and restaurants, and did I mention, it's all climate controlled.

Google is not alone. By the way, tech titans like LinkedIn and Facebook also on a real estate buying binge prepping pricey headquarters to cook up new inventions. So what the tech are they planning? Find out tomorrow, the hottest news segment in all of cable news.

Every day we bring you the latest, the coolest before anyone else is talking about it. A way for you to profit off of it and not just because it might have been the inspiration for Tom Cruise in vanilla sky, that's up to you. That's up to you. Run with it. We're looking out for you.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5R6W-BGB1-DY9P-N27H-00000-00FINANCIAL ICONOCLAST2017-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:49ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 64,65,66,67FINANCIAL ICONOCLASTAlison Tudor-Ackroyd

Ant Financial's chief strategy officer, Chen Long, talks about the fintech firm's plans to rebuild finance to fit in with customers' needs Ant Financial, the private company behind China's largest digital payment service provider Alipay, has plans to shake up financial services globally.

In a wide-ranging conversation with FinanceAsia, its chief strategy officer, Chen Long, covered topics from the direction of financial regulation in China at a time when Beijing is looking to secure more control over the Big Tech to the firm's overseas expansion plans.

Long, a former finance professor who joined Ant Financial in 2014, also delved into controversial areas such as customer privacy in the era of big data, as well as how the firm defends itself against cyberattacks and what China's ban on initial coin offerings (ICOs) in September means for financial innovation.

He also identified the area of finance services he thinks mosts needs rebuilding: insurance. "We think it has to be broken - something has to change," Long said.

Ant Financial has the firepower and data to do it.

The unit of China's top ecommerce firm Alibaba has collected and stored customer's payment records, creating a large pool of information that allows lenders and insurers to conduct credit assessments effectively.

"Alipay generates invaluable data for a datacentric group," according to Piyush Mubayi, a Goldman Sachs equity analyst.

Ant Financial plans to serve two billion customers globally in a decade, versus its current customer mix of 463 million in China, 12 million across the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and a further 180 million at Paytm in India. Ant's $1.2 billion bid for Dallas-based money transfer service MoneyGram International is under review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (Cfius). Ant Financial is "on track to be the world's largest fintech company," Mubayi said.

Investors are understandably excited about Ant Financial's prospects and plans ahead of its public listing, tipped for next year. The IPO has the potential to be the largest fundraising ever by a fintech innovator.

Ant Financial will still be 33% owned by Alibaba if the company is listed in the future, according to Alibaba's annual report.

Ant Financial is already estimated to be worth more than $70.5 billion, according to equity analysts at Goldman Sachs; bigger than the market capitalisation of Swiss bank UBS.

First developed as an online payment system for Alibaba's internet marketplace, its Alipay mobile payment platform has expanded into the physical world, enabling users to make payments instantly by scanning the QR codes in their smart phone.

It took a step further on September 1, deploying its facial recognition payment system "Smile to Pay" at a Yum China restaurant in its hometown of Hangzhou.

Chen also addressed fears that Ant's online money fund Yu'e Bao, meaning leftover treasure, has grown so large it poses a systemic risk.

The following transcript of the conversation has been edited for clarity.

Q Which areas of finance overseas offer the most promising opportunities for digital disruption and growth for Ant Financial? A There is so much that can be done in payments, wealth management, consumer loans, SME [small-and medium-sized enterprise] loans and insurance.

Finance is so far from being inclusive that we see blue ocean everywhere.

In the US, payments are very out dated, even though it is the most advanced financial system in the world.

People should have their own balance sheet to manage their financial life. It will come and it will come fast.

Finance will be democratised, just like at Yu'e Bao. You have just one yuan? You can still grow it. At a traditional bank if you only have a little money, then who is going to talk to you? Q What will you do with MoneyGram if Ant's acquisition is approved? A I can't discuss that but what I can say is that international cross border payments cost up to 7% globally - more than twice as high as it needs to be.

Q What are your plans for growing "Smile to Pay"? A There are different ways to complete payments. One of them is facial technology, but it's not clear if it will become the most widely used way to complete payments in the future.

The key yardstick is the users' experience.

We started with QR code payments [scannable codes that resemble square mazes], which became extremely popular.

When Apple Pay came out with its version of NFC [near field communications] payments there was quite some excitement, but it is far from being the major player.

Whatever payment method is most widely used will evolve the fastest and dominate payments.

Safety is not the major concern for payments - because transactions are already very safe, thanks to our AI-driven risk management system.

Our fraud loss rate is already lower than 1 in 1 million, meaning that for every one million dollars there is one dollar of loss.

That is better than bank debit or credit cards in China. Their official average loss rate is estimated to be about two basis points [0.02%]. Also bear in mind that China's bank loss rate is low compared with the rest of the world.

Q Don't people worry about privacy? Will this hamper Ant Financial's development? A Privacy and data security are the building blocks of the digital age. People kind of assume in the big data age that their data will be detected and watched, but that is not the case.

Any data that is collected has to be authorised. Then before any one can use it the data has to go through desensitisation, which means it will be made anonymous- no one will know you. Then the third step is that it will be encrypted. Even if someone steals your data they won't be able to read it - there is a lock on it. After that, then people inside Ant Financial can start to analyse the data and use it.

In the big data age we understand you very well but we don't know you - you are like a familiar stranger.

Without this protection finance would never progress - the business would be unsustainable. We're just starting to take advantage of data to serve the customer well - it is crucial.

Right now we think it is big data but 30 years from now the amount of data could be 500,000 times bigger.

But in the meantime the challenge of privacy protection and data security has just started.

Q But aren't hackers becoming ever more sophisticated and cyber attacks increasingly frequent? A This is the war everyone faces in the digital age including traditional banks.

Ant faces many cyberattacks every day, which gives us a lot of experience. We've seen the most attacks and we've learnt a lot from them. This means attackers have not yet been able to outsmart us thus far, but you can never say never.

Q What is Ant doing in the field of insurance? A We probably have the largest number of insurance users in the world. More than 350 million people have used one of the insurance products on our platforms, such as shipping return insurance.

This is a classic example of how you can entirely design and change an insurance product through technology. If you buy this [shipping return] insurance you can return items bought online for free if you end up returning the products you bought.

We worked with an insurance company - which used its own actuarial techniques to set rates.

The insurance company lost tens of millions in half a year for this shipping return product, so our big data and AI department worked closely with them in order to better identify risk. As a result they could distinguish between who would return items more often. With our big data analysis they were able to slash premiums for most people. In the end everyone bought the product.

Shipping return insurance is a very cheap product but this is something we really care about - why do we care? Because according to studies without this insurance a customer would buy a bit less online.

The product actually stimulates consumption, creating a virtuous circle.

It is also good for the merchants because it reduces their costs. Before this insurance, whenever customers had a bad experience they would call the merchants and fight with them. So the merchants had to hire a big customer service force. With this insurance product, whenever the client is unhappy he gets paid and no need for long phone conversations with customer service.

This is a typical example of how financial innovation can solve a pain point in life.

Another example is account safety insurance.

You may have some money in Alipay but you might be worried about fraud and account theft so you buy insurance. It costs just one or two yuan to insure $1 million equivalent against fraud and identity theft.

We think insurance probably has the highest pain point among financial services.

Almost everyone doesn't know which insurance policy to buy or who to trust: it's like a black box. In other areas like payments, wealth management, or consumer loans you have seen some innovation, but in insurance, eh-eh, not so much.

We think it has to be broken - something has to change.

Big data will help better price risk, for the benefit of everyone.

In car insurance a huge chunk of the cost is to verify the size of the loss in the case of an accident.

Now, you only need to take a picture and our image recognition-driven car exterior assessment technology, which we provided to several insurance companies, will tell you that the accident will cost you this much and recommend whether you should report to your insurance company or not (which might raise your premiums for next year). [Called scratch and dent insurance in the US]. Also it tells you where the nearest garage is for help.

Big data will also help reconstruct the experience of dealing with an insurance company. Insurance companies are running up to us to work with us on this.

We have developed a credit scorecard for car insurance - like a FICO score - so we can help insurance companies distinguish good drivers and bad drivers.

Q Who owns the end customer when you partner with an insurance company? A It has to be beneficial to both sides and somehow it has to be sustainable.

We are better in using technology to reconstruct the users' experience and better at reaching the customers. Financial institutions have reputation, they have capital, they know how to design financial products. A lot of fund managers use Ant Fortune [an investing app]. They feel like this is their home; it's a platform linking them together and we give them a lot of technical support.

Q Yu'e Bao has grown so fast and it is so large that some people are worried about systematic risk? How does Ant Financial view this potential problem? A Yu'e Bao is a typical money market fund - it is pocket money for the online shoppers. Yu'e Bao is liquid, unleveraged, fully disclosed and transparent. Risk is quite low. Money market funds are a different animal - they can only invest in best short-term debt. Also unlike banks, money market funds don't have leverage.

Money market funds were first created in 1971 in the United States and they have never cost the taxpayers a penny. As far as I am aware, and I have studied this, there are only two funds that have lost any principal capital.

History tells us that thus far it is a reasonable regulatory arrangement.

The role of finance is not to kill risk, it is to balance the risk and benefits. Banks manage a mismatch in duration.

Q Are know-yourcustomer requirements loosening up? A KYC is important. Identification [verification] is the basis of finance. So we spend a lot of time on it. [If there is a more secure, efficient and user-friendly indentification verification system] then it benefits everyone including banks and us. The basis of finance is KYC. You can go as far as your KYC stretches. If you cannot get comfortable with a customer and his/her identity, don't serve them.

Q Does China's crackdown on Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs) suggest China is being less tolerant of financial innovation generally? A There must be some regulation of ICOs otherwise a lot of people's money will be lost. To a large extent China is right to tighten regulations.

It is very hard for regulators to balance the benefits and risk. In the US, after the financial crisis regulation became so tight that banks don't have much life any more.

China is indeed emphasising more security these days for the whole financial sector.

Regulations have cycles just like business has cycles.

The biggest bubble in Chinese fintech that we have already experienced was in P2P [peer-to-peer lending]. More than two thirds of P2Ps went under, and more will follow.

Back in 2014 Alipay made the decision not to provide payment services for P2P.

ICOs have taken only a few months to go through the same cycle that P2P went through across several years.

The combination of blockchain, bitcoin and the IPO creates a lot of uncertainty.

Yet the fintech trend is irreversible, and we believe that it will integrate into life, I call it FinLife. But in some areas it can afford to take a little break. FA

"Finance ; ; is so far ; ; from being ; ; inclusive ; ; that we see ; ; blue ocean ; ; everywhere" ; ;

"The role of finance is not to ; ; kill risk, it is to balance the ; ; risk and benefits" ; ;
